Returns the entropy over labellings of the given sequence. This is given by:
Ground Truth link: h(o) = - sum_s pr(s | o) log pr(s | o)
Program link: h(o) = - sum_s pr(s | o) log pr(s | o)

Paragraph: Returns the entropy over labellings of the given sequence. This is given by:
Ground Truth link: h(o) = - sum_s pr(s | o) log pr(s | o)
Program link: h = - sum_s pr(s | o) log [ pr(s, o) / z ] = log z - sum_s pr(s | o) log pr(s, 0) = log z - sum_s pr(s | o) [ log pr(s_0) + sum_t pr(s_t | s_{t-1}) + sum_t pr(o_t | s_t) ]

Paragraph: The order of summation for the log terms can be flipped, allowing dynamic programming to be used to calculate the entropy. Specifically, we use the forward and backward probabilities (alpha, beta) giving:
Ground Truth link:
h = log z - sum_s0 alpha_0(s0) beta_0(s0) / z * log pr(s0)
+ sum_t,si,sj alpha_t(si) pr(sj | si) pr(o_t+1 | sj) beta_t(sj) / z * log pr(sj | si)
+ sum_t,st alpha_t(st) beta_t(st) / z * log pr(o_t | st)
Program link: h = log z - sum_s0 alpha_0(s0) beta_0(s0) / z * log pr(s0) + sum_t,si,sj alpha_t(si) pr(sj | si) pr(o_t+1 | sj) beta_t(sj) / z * log pr(sj | si) + sum_t,st alpha_t(st) beta_t(st) / z * log pr(o_t | st)

Paragraph: This class communicates with the hunpos-tag binary via pipes. When the tagger object is no longer needed, the close() method should be called to free system resources. The class supports the context manager interface; if used in a with statement, the close() method is invoked automatically:
Ground Truth link:
>>> with hunpostagger('en_wsj.model') as ht:
...     ht.tag('what is the airspeed of an unladen swallow ?'.split())
...
[('what', 'wp'), ('is', 'vbz'), ('the', 'dt'), ('airspeed', 'nn'), ('of', 'in'), ('an', 'dt'), ('unladen', 'nn'), ('swallow', 'vb'), ('?', '.')]
Program link: >>> with hunpostagger('en_wsj.model') as ht: ... ht.tag('what is the airspeed of an unladen swallow ?'.split()) ... [('what', 'wp'), ('is', 'vbz'), ('the', 'dt'), ('airspeed', 'nn'), ('of', 'in'), ('an', 'dt'), ('unladen', 'nn'), ('swallow', 'vb'), ('?', '.')]

A tagger that assigns the same tag to every token.
Ground Truth link:
>>> from nltk.tag import defaulttagger
>>> default_tagger = defaulttagger('nn')
>>> list(default_tagger.tag('this is a test'.split()))
[('this', 'nn'), ('is', 'nn'), ('a', 'nn'), ('test', 'nn')]
Program link: >>> from nltk.tag import defaulttagger >>> default_tagger = defaulttagger('nn') >>> list(default_tagger.tag('this is a test'.split())) [('this', 'nn'), ('is', 'nn'), ('a', 'nn'), ('test', 'nn')]

Paragraph: The RegexpTagger assigns tags to tokens by comparing their word strings to a series of regular expressions. The following tagger uses word suffixes to make guesses about the correct Brown Corpus part of speech tag:
Ground Truth link:
>>> from nltk.corpus import brown
>>> from nltk.tag import regexptagger
>>> test_sent = brown.sents(categories='news')[0]
>>> regexp_tagger = regexptagger(
...     [(r'^-?[0-9]+(.[0-9]+)?$', 'cd'),   # cardinal numbers
...      (r'(the|the|a|a|an|an)$', 'at'),   # articles
...      (r'.*able$', 'jj'),                # adjectives
...      (r'.*ness$', 'nn'),                # nouns formed from adjectives
...      (r'.*ly$', 'rb'),                  # adverbs
...      (r'.*s$', 'nns'),                  # plural nouns
...      (r'.*ing$', 'vbg'),                # gerunds
...      (r'.*ed$', 'vbd'),                 # past tense verbs
...      (r'.*', 'nn')                      # nouns (default)
... ])
>>> regexp_tagger
<regexp tagger: size=9>
>>> regexp_tagger.tag(test_sent)
[('the', 'at'), ('fulton', 'nn'), ('county', 'nn'), ('grand', 'nn'), ('jury', 'nn'),
('said', 'nn'), ('friday', 'nn'), ('an', 'at'), ('investigation', 'nn'), ('of', 'nn'),
("atlanta's", 'nns'), ('recent', 'nn'), ('primary', 'nn'), ('election', 'nn'),
('produced', 'vbd'), ('``', 'nn'), ('no', 'nn'), ('evidence', 'nn'), ("''", 'nn'),
('that', 'nn'), ('any', 'nn'), ('irregularities', 'nns'), ('took', 'nn'),
('place', 'nn'), ('.', 'nn')]
Program link:
>>> from nltk.corpus import brown >>> from nltk.tag import regexptagger >>> test_sent = brown.sents(categories='news')[0] >>> regexp_tagger = regexptagger( ... [(r'^-?[0-9]+(.[0-9]+)?$', 'cd'), # cardinal numbers ... (r'(the|the|a|a|an|an)$', 'at'), # articles ... (r'.*able$', 'jj'), # adjectives ... (r'.*ness$', 'nn'), # nouns formed from adjectives ... (r'.*ly$', 'rb'), # adverbs ... (r'.*s$', 'nns'), # plural nouns ... (r'.*ing$', 'vbg'), # gerunds ... (r'.*ed$', 'vbd'), # past tense verbs ... (r'.*', 'nn') # nouns (default) ... ]) >>> regexp_tagger
>>> regexp_tagger.tag(test_sent) [('the', 'at'), ('fulton', 'nn'), ('county', 'nn'), ('grand', 'nn'), ('jury', 'nn'), ('said', 'nn'), ('friday', 'nn'), ('an', 'at'), ('investigation', 'nn'), ('of', 'nn'), ("atlanta's", 'nns'), ('recent', 'nn'), ('primary', 'nn'), ('election', 'nn'), ('produced', 'vbd'), ('``', 'nn'), ('no', 'nn'), ('evidence', 'nn'), ("''", 'nn'), ('that', 'nn'), ('any', 'nn'), ('irregularities', 'nns'), ('took', 'nn'), ('place', 'nn'), ('.', 'nn')]

Paragraph: The UnigramTagger finds the most likely tag for each word in a training corpus, and then uses that information to assign tags to new tokens.
Ground Truth link:
>>> from nltk.corpus import brown
>>> from nltk.tag import unigramtagger
>>> test_sent = brown.sents(categories='news')[0]
>>> unigram_tagger = unigramtagger(brown.tagged_sents(categories='news')[:500])
>>> for tok, tag in unigram_tagger.tag(test_sent):
...     print("({}, {}), ".format(tok, tag))
(the, at), (fulton, np-tl), (county, nn-tl), (grand, jj-tl),
(jury, nn-tl), (said, vbd), (friday, nr), (an, at),
(investigation, nn), (of, in), (atlanta's, np$), (recent, jj),
(primary, nn), (election, nn), (produced, vbd), (``, ``),
(no, at), (evidence, nn), ('', ''), (that, cs), (any, dti),
(irregularities, nns), (took, vbd), (place, nn), (., .),
Program link: >>> from nltk.corpus import brown >>> from nltk.tag import unigramtagger >>> test_sent = brown.sents(categories='news')[0] >>> unigram_tagger = unigramtagger(brown.tagged_sents(categories='news')[:500]) >>> for tok, tag in unigram_tagger.tag(test_sent): ... print("({}, {}), ".format(tok, tag)) (the, at), (fulton, np-tl), (county, nn-tl), (grand, jj-tl), (jury, nn-tl), (said, vbd), (friday, nr), (an, at), (investigation, nn), (of, in), (atlanta's, np$), (recent, jj), (primary, nn), (election, nn), (produced, vbd), (``, ``), (no, at), (evidence, nn), ('', ''), (that, cs), (any, dti), (irregularities, nns), (took, vbd), (place, nn), (., .),

Paragraph: Given the string representation of a tagged token, return the corresponding tuple representation. The rightmost occurrence of sep in s will be used to divide s into a word string and a tag string. If sep does not occur in s, return (s, None).

Given the tuple representation of a tagged token, return the corresponding string representation. This representation is formed by concatenating the token’s word string, followed by the separator, followed by the token’s tag. (If the tag is None, then just return the bare word string.)
Ground Truth link:
>>> from nltk.tag.util import tuple2str
>>> tagged_token = ('fly', 'nn')
>>> tuple2str(tagged_token)
'fly/nn'
Program link: >>> from nltk.tag.util import tuple2str >>> tagged_token = ('fly', 'nn') >>> tuple2str(tagged_token) 'fly/nn'

Paragraph: Given a tagged sentence, return an untagged version of that sentence. I.e., return a list containing the first element of each tuple in tagged_sentence.

A “tag” is a case-sensitive string that specifies some property of a token, such as its part of speech. Tagged tokens are encoded as tuples (tag, token). For example, the following tagged token combines the word 'fly' with a noun part of speech tag ('NN'):
An off-the-shelf tagger is available for English. It uses the Penn Treebank tagset:
Ground Truth link:
>>> from nltk import pos_tag, word_tokenize
>>> pos_tag(word_tokenize("john's big idea isn't all that bad."))
[('john', 'nnp'), ("'s", 'pos'), ('big', 'jj'), ('idea', 'nn'), ('is', 'vbz'),
("n't", 'rb'), ('all', 'pdt'), ('that', 'dt'), ('bad', 'jj'), ('.', '.')]
Program link: >>> from nltk import pos_tag, word_tokenize >>> pos_tag(word_tokenize("john's big idea isn't all that bad.")) [('john', 'nnp'), ("'s", 'pos'), ('big', 'jj'), ('idea', 'nn'), ('is', 'vbz'), ("n't", 'rb'), ('all', 'pdt'), ('that', 'dt'), ('bad', 'jj'), ('.', '.')]

Paragraph: A Russian tagger is also available if you specify lang=”rus”. It uses the Russian National Corpus tagset:
Ground Truth link:
>>> pos_tag(word_tokenize("илья оторопел и дважды перечитал бумажку."), lang='rus')    
[('илья', 's'), ('оторопел', 'v'), ('и', 'conj'), ('дважды', 'adv'), ('перечитал', 'v'),
('бумажку', 's'), ('.', 'nonlex')]
Program link: >>> pos_tag(word_tokenize("илья оторопел и дважды перечитал бумажку."), lang='rus') [('илья', 's'), ('оторопел', 'v'), ('и', 'conj'), ('дважды', 'adv'), ('перечитал', 'v'), ('бумажку', 's'), ('.', 'nonlex')]

Paragraph: This package defines several taggers, which take a list of tokens, assign a tag to each one, and return the resulting list of tagged tokens. Most of the taggers are built automatically based on a training corpus. For example, the unigram tagger tags each word w by checking what the most frequent tag for w was in a training corpus:
Ground Truth link:
>>> from nltk.corpus import brown
>>> from nltk.tag import unigramtagger
>>> tagger = unigramtagger(brown.tagged_sents(categories='news')[:500])
>>> sent = ['mitchell', 'decried', 'the', 'high', 'rate', 'of', 'unemployment']
>>> for word, tag in tagger.tag(sent):
...     print(word, '->', tag)
mitchell -> np
decried -> none
the -> at
high -> jj
rate -> nn
of -> in
unemployment -> none
Program link: >>> from nltk.corpus import brown >>> from nltk.tag import unigramtagger >>> tagger = unigramtagger(brown.tagged_sents(categories='news')[:500]) >>> sent = ['mitchell', 'decried', 'the', 'high', 'rate', 'of', 'unemployment'] >>> for word, tag in tagger.tag(sent): ... print(word, '->', tag) mitchell -> np decried -> none the -> at high -> jj rate -> nn of -> in unemployment -> none

Ground Truth link:
>>> backoff = regexptagger([
... (r'^-?[0-9]+(.[0-9]+)?$', 'cd'),   # cardinal numbers
... (r'(the|the|a|a|an|an)$', 'at'),   # articles
... (r'.*able$', 'jj'),                # adjectives
... (r'.*ness$', 'nn'),                # nouns formed from adjectives
... (r'.*ly$', 'rb'),                  # adverbs
... (r'.*s$', 'nns'),                  # plural nouns
... (r'.*ing$', 'vbg'),                # gerunds
... (r'.*ed$', 'vbd'),                 # past tense verbs
... (r'.*', 'nn')                      # nouns (default)
... ])

Paragraph: where the summation ranges over all state sequences, S. Let Z = Pr(O) = sum_S Pr(S, O)} where the summation ranges over all state sequences and O is the observation sequence. As such the entropy can be re-expressed as:
Ground Truth link:
h = - sum_s pr(s | o) log [ pr(s, o) / z ]
= log z - sum_s pr(s | o) log pr(s, 0)
= log z - sum_s pr(s | o) [ log pr(s_0) + sum_t pr(s_t | s_{t-1}) + sum_t pr(o_t | s_t) ]

Paragraph: A class for pos tagging with HunPos. The input is the paths to:
Ground Truth link:
>>> from nltk.tag import hunpostagger
>>> ht = hunpostagger('en_wsj.model')
>>> ht.tag('what is the airspeed of an unladen swallow ?'.split())
[('what', 'wp'), ('is', 'vbz'), ('the', 'dt'), ('airspeed', 'nn'), ('of', 'in'), ('an', 'dt'), ('unladen', 'nn'), ('swallow', 'vb'), ('?', '.')]
>>> ht.close()

('of', 'in'), ('an', 'dt'), ('unladen', 'nn'), ('swallow', 'nn'), ('?', '.')]

>>> from nltk.tag import sennachunktagger
>>> chktagger = sennachunktagger('/usr/share/senna-v3.0')
>>> chktagger.tag('what is the airspeed of an unladen swallow ?'.split()) 
[('what', 'b-np'), ('is', 'b-vp'), ('the', 'b-np'), ('airspeed', 'i-np'),
('of', 'b-pp'), ('an', 'b-np'), ('unladen', 'i-np'), ('swallow', 'i-np'),
('?', 'o')]

Paragraph: SennaTagger will automatically search for executable file specified in SENNA environment variable
Ground Truth link:
>>> from nltk.tag import sennanertagger
>>> nertagger = sennanertagger('/usr/share/senna-v3.0')
>>> nertagger.tag('shakespeare theatre was in london .'.split()) 
[('shakespeare', 'b-per'), ('theatre', 'o'), ('was', 'o'), ('in', 'o'),
('london', 'b-loc'), ('.', 'o')]
>>> nertagger.tag('un headquarters are in ny , usa .'.split()) 
[('un', 'b-org'), ('headquarters', 'o'), ('are', 'o'), ('in', 'o'),
('ny', 'b-loc'), (',', 'o'), ('usa', 'b-loc'), ('.', 'o')]

Paragraph: Extracts the chunks in a BIO chunk-tagged sentence.
Ground Truth link:
>>> from nltk.tag import sennachunktagger
>>> chktagger = sennachunktagger('/usr/share/senna-v3.0')
>>> sent = 'what is the airspeed of an unladen swallow ?'.split()
>>> tagged_sent = chktagger.tag(sent) 
>>> tagged_sent 
[('what', 'b-np'), ('is', 'b-vp'), ('the', 'b-np'), ('airspeed', 'i-np'),
('of', 'b-pp'), ('an', 'b-np'), ('unladen', 'i-np'), ('swallow', 'i-np'),
('?', 'o')]
>>> list(chktagger.bio_to_chunks(tagged_sent, chunk_type='np')) 
[('what', '0'), ('the airspeed', '2-3'), ('an unladen swallow', '5-6-7')]

Paragraph: A class for Named-Entity Tagging with Stanford Tagger. The input is the paths to:
Ground Truth link:
>>> from nltk.tag import stanfordnertagger
>>> st = stanfordnertagger('english.all.3class.distsim.crf.ser.gz') 
>>> st.tag('rami eid is studying at stony brook university in ny'.split()) 
[('rami', 'person'), ('eid', 'person'), ('is', 'o'), ('studying', 'o'),
 ('at', 'o'), ('stony', 'organization'), ('brook', 'organization'),
 ('university', 'organization'), ('in', 'o'), ('ny', 'location')]

Paragraph: A class for pos tagging with Stanford Tagger. The input is the paths to:
Ground Truth link:
>>> from nltk.tag import stanfordpostagger
>>> st = stanfordpostagger('english-bidirectional-distsim.tagger')
>>> st.tag('what is the airspeed of an unladen swallow ?'.split())
[('what', 'wp'), ('is', 'vbz'), ('the', 'dt'), ('airspeed', 'nn'), ('of', 'in'), ('an', 'dt'), ('unladen', 'jj'), ('swallow', 'vb'), ('?', '.')]

Paragraph: We evaluate a tagger on data that was not seen during training:
Use NLTK’s currently recommended part of speech tagger to tag the given list of tokens.
Ground Truth link:
>>> from nltk.tag import pos_tag
>>> from nltk.tokenize import word_tokenize
>>> pos_tag(word_tokenize("john's big idea isn't all that bad."))
[('john', 'nnp'), ("'s", 'pos'), ('big', 'jj'), ('idea', 'nn'), ('is', 'vbz'),
("n't", 'rb'), ('all', 'pdt'), ('that', 'dt'), ('bad', 'jj'), ('.', '.')]
>>> pos_tag(word_tokenize("john's big idea isn't all that bad."), tagset='universal')
[('john', 'noun'), ("'s", 'prt'), ('big', 'adj'), ('idea', 'noun'), ('is', 'verb'),
("n't", 'adv'), ('all', 'det'), ('that', 'det'), ('bad', 'adj'), ('.', '.')]

Paragraph: Trains the Brill tagger on the corpus train_sents, producing at most max_rules transformations, each of which reduces the net number of errors in the corpus by at least min_score, and each of which has accuracy not lower than min_acc.
Program link: >>> backoff = regexptagger([ ... (r'^-?[0-9]+(.[0-9]+)?$', 'cd'), # cardinal numbers ... (r'(the|the|a|a|an|an)$', 'at'), # articles ... (r'.*able$', 'jj'), # adjectives ... (r'.*ness$', 'nn'), # nouns formed from adjectives ... (r'.*ly$', 'rb'), # adverbs ... (r'.*s$', 'nns'), # plural nouns ... (r'.*ing$', 'vbg'), # gerunds ... (r'.*ed$', 'vbd'), # past tense verbs ... (r'.*', 'nn') # nouns (default) ... ])

Paragraph: Trains the Brill tagger on the corpus train_sents, producing at most max_rules transformations, each of which reduces the net number of errors in the corpus by at least min_score, and each of which has accuracy not lower than min_acc.

Program link: >>> from nltk.tag import sennatagger >>> tagger = sennatagger('/usr/share/senna-v3.0') >>> tagger.tag('what is the airspeed of an unladen swallow ?'.split()) [('what', 'wp'), ('is', 'vbz'), ('the', 'dt'), ('airspeed', 'nn'), ('of', 'in'), ('an', 'dt'), ('unladen', 'nn'), ('swallow', 'nn'), ('?', '.')]

Program link: >>> from nltk.tag import sennanertagger >>> nertagger = sennanertagger('/usr/share/senna-v3.0') >>> nertagger.tag('shakespeare theatre was in london .'.split()) [('shakespeare', 'b-per'), ('theatre', 'o'), ('was', 'o'), ('in', 'o'), ('london', 'b-loc'), ('.', 'o')] >>> nertagger.tag('un headquarters are in ny , usa .'.split()) [('un', 'b-org'), ('headquarters', 'o'), ('are', 'o'), ('in', 'o'), ('ny', 'b-loc'), (',', 'o'), ('usa', 'b-loc'), ('.', 'o')]
